primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in a world held captive by the cosmic power of Sin to liberate humanity through the righteousness of Jesus Christ.

tekstueel_bewijs: God put forward [Christ] as an expiation
God had acted in Jesus Christ powerfully to impute his righteousness
He comes to meet us and liberate us

object.identificatie: The Righteousness of God / Deliverance of Humanity
tekstueel_bewijs: the righteousness of God has been manifested
acquittal and life for all men

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Gospel itself
tekstueel_bewijs: the proclamation of the Christian faith never begins with sin, but with grace
the power of God for salvation

ontvanger.identificatie: All who believe / The Human Race
tekstueel_bewijs: leads to acquittal and life for all men

helper.identificatie: Jesus Christ / The Apostle Paul (as witness) / The Holy Spirit (implied in grace)
tekstueel_bewijs: through the redemption which is in Christ Jesus

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin (Capital 'S'), Death, and the Wrath of God (as opposition to Sin)
tekstueel_bewijs: an enslaving power external to man
the evil Power than holds his creatures in bondage
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described not as a mistake but as an 'alien power' and 'primordial catastrophe' that humanity cannot escape on its own.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The hearer recognizing their own bondage and receiving the news of salvation.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer / Martin Luther (as archetype)
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Knowledge of Sin / Peace with God
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (human response) is strictly a result of the primary program (God's action). 'You cannot know that you are lost until deliverance has begun to dawn on you.'

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has acted in Jesus Christ
He comes to meet us and liberate us
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we stubbornly refuse to see it
we cling to the myth of our own innocence

voorbeelden: If we are not prepared to talk about sin, we really cannot read the Bible
will we read the letters of Paul as secondary...?
the knowledge of Sin is given only to those who have begun to know the mercy of God
the power of God for salvation
Sin and Death no longer have dominion

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Power' (Pouvoir) of God overcoming the 'Power' of Sin. Human 'Devoir' is rendered impossible by Sin, thus God provides the 'Pouvoir' through Christ.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From the 'old condemned life' (~S1) through the 'Wrath' (S2) to the 'world-transforming now' (~S2) into 'Righteousness' (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The resolution is found in the 'fusion' of wrath and mercy at the Cross, where God justifies the ungodly.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; Sin is treated as a cosmic enemy, not a moral lapse.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is rigorously theocentric. God is the primary actor; humans are the receivers of a deliverance they cannot initiate.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Luther is used as an example of despair, but his breakthrough is credited to the text/God, not his effort.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of active verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God had acted in Jesus Christ powerfully to impute his righteousness
Sin is the fundamental condition of man... an enslaving power external to man

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Luther is used as a narrative mirror for the hearer's despair, but the 'hero' of Luther's story is the Word of God.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God saves Luther through the Word.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and assurance; moving from 'troubled' to 'rejoicing'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic salvation; God does the work, man receives the benefit.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The narrative hierarchy is perfectly maintained: God's act (Soteriology) precedes and enables human awareness and response.
spanning_punten: The paradox that one only knows sin after grace has arrived.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: the Judge himself had gotten up off the bench and come down into the dock to stand alongside the guilty prisoner

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses on Christ and the Word; the Spirit's role is implicit in the 'power' of the Gospel.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; Sin is an 'alien power' and 'enslaving'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a masterclass in theocentric narrative. God is the Subject of all redemptive action.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for a sermon on Romans 3.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon perfectly exemplifies the 'Grammar of Grace' by keeping God as the Subject of the active verbs of salvation.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis might focus on the use of the 'But now' pivot, Greimasian analysis shows this pivot is actually a Subject-switch from Sin's dominion to God's action.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Greek word for righteousness; semiotics shows how that word functions as the 'Object' of value transferred from Sender to Receiver.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Heavy Opponent' (Sin with a capital S), which necessitates a Divine Subject, ruling out any moralistic 'Helper' theology.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'But now' as a semiotic hinge between two aeons.
